debates.regulationTitle: RBI Data Localization - Payment System Data Storage
debates.summary: New RBI circular mandating all payment system operators to store complete payment data exclusively in India within 24 hours of processing

proposer.position: The circular requires IMMEDIATE localization of ALL payment data including transaction logs, customer credentials, and payment instrument details. Recommend blocking any cross-border data transfer and implementing real-time data mirroring to India-based servers.
reasoning: RBI circular explicitly states 'entire data relating to payment systems' must be stored in India
Previous RBI enforcement actions show zero tolerance for data localization violations
Penalty of up to Rs. 1 crore per violation under Payment and Settlement Systems Act

critic.position: While data localization is mandatory, the circular allows for processing to occur abroad with a copy stored in India. Completely blocking cross-border transfer would disrupt international card network operations (Visa/Mastercard) which require real-time authorization from global servers.
reasoning: RBI clarification dated 2019 allows processing abroad if data is deleted within 24 hours
Card network authorization requires millisecond latency - local-only would break transactions
Focus should be on 'storage' not 'processing' per RBI's own FAQ

judge.decision: Allow real-time processing via international card networks. Mandate that all payment data be mirrored to India-based servers within 1 business day. Delete any data stored outside India within 24 hours of settlement. Implement audit trail for cross-border data flows.
judge.requirement: Payment data must be stored exclusively in India; cross-border processing allowed with 24-hour deletion
reasoning: Balances operational necessity with regulatory compliance
Aligns with RBI's stated intent of data sovereignty
Provides clear implementation path without disrupting payment flows

debates.regulationTitle: DPDP Act - Consent Manager Framework Implementation
debates.summary: MeitY notification on mandatory Consent Manager integration for all Data Fiduciaries processing personal data of Indian residents

proposer.position: DPDP Act Section 6 mandates explicit consent for all personal data processing. We must implement a Consent Manager that allows granular consent withdrawal at any time. Recommend blocking all data processing activities that lack documented consent.
reasoning: DPDP Act treats consent as the primary lawful basis for processing
Penalties up to Rs. 250 crore for processing without valid consent
Data Principal rights include withdrawal of consent at any time

critic.position: Section 7 of DPDP Act provides for 'legitimate uses' that don't require consent - including fraud prevention, network security, and credit scoring. Blocking all processing without consent would break essential financial services and fraud detection systems.
reasoning: Section 7(a) explicitly allows processing for 'prevention of fraud'
KYC processing is mandated by RBI - consent alone doesn't apply
Transaction monitoring for AML is a legal requirement under PMLA

judge.decision: Implement Consent Manager for voluntary data collection (marketing, analytics). Exempt fraud prevention, KYC, and AML monitoring from consent requirements under Section 7. Create clear audit logs distinguishing consent-based vs legitimate-use processing.
judge.requirement: Consent Manager required for marketing/analytics; legitimate use exemption for fraud prevention and regulatory compliance
reasoning: Respects DPDP Act's consent-first principle
Preserves essential financial crime prevention capabilities
Creates defensible position with clear documentation

debates.summary: CERT-In direction requiring all service providers to report cybersecurity incidents within 6 hours of detection

proposer.position: CERT-In Direction mandates reporting of 20+ incident types within 6 hours. This includes data breaches, malware attacks, and unauthorized access. Recommend implementing automated incident detection and immediate CERT-In notification pipeline.
reasoning: 6-hour window is extremely tight for manual reporting
Non-compliance can result in blocking of services
Automation is essential for meeting timeline

critic.position: While 6-hour reporting is mandatory, the direction allows for initial notification with details to follow. Over-reporting false positives could overwhelm CERT-In and create unnecessary regulatory scrutiny. Need threshold-based detection to filter noise.
reasoning: CERT-In FAQ allows 'initial intimation' within 6 hours with details later
False positive reports create compliance overhead
Risk-based approach needed to prioritize genuine incidents

judge.decision: Implement automated incident detection with severity classification. Auto-report high/critical incidents to CERT-In within 4 hours (buffer for review). Medium severity requires human confirmation within 6-hour window. Maintain detailed logs for all detections.
judge.requirement: Automated incident detection with 6-hour CERT-In reporting; severity-based escalation
reasoning: Meets 6-hour mandate with time buffer
Reduces false positive noise through severity filtering
Maintains audit trail for regulatory defense

debates.regulationTitle: RBI Video KYC Enhancement - Liveness Detection Mandate
debates.summary: Amendment to Video-based Customer Identification Process (V-CIP) requiring AI-based liveness detection and deepfake prevention

proposer.position: RBI amendment mandates liveness detection to prevent deepfake fraud in Video KYC. Recommend immediate integration of certified liveness detection SDK and blocking all V-CIP without liveness verification.
reasoning: Deepfake fraud in V-CIP has increased 340% in 2025
RBI circular explicitly requires 'technological measures to detect spoofing'
Non-compliant V-CIP completions will be invalidated

critic.position: While liveness detection is required, the amendment provides 90-day implementation window. Immediately blocking V-CIP would halt customer onboarding. Need phased rollout with fallback to physical KYC for edge cases.
reasoning: 90-day compliance window mentioned in circular
Physical KYC remains valid alternative
Some legitimate customers may fail liveness check (elderly, poor connectivity)

judge.decision: Phase 1 (Week 1-2): Integrate liveness SDK in shadow mode, collect metrics. Phase 2 (Week 3-6): Enable liveness with fallback to physical KYC. Phase 3 (Week 7-12): Mandatory liveness, physical KYC only for documented exceptions.
judge.requirement: AI-based liveness detection mandatory for V-CIP with documented exception process
reasoning: Respects 90-day timeline
Provides fallback for edge cases
Creates audit trail for exceptions

debates.regulationTitle: NPCI UPI Transaction Limit Enhancement - High Value Payments
debates.summary: NPCI circular increasing UPI transaction limit to Rs. 5 lakhs for specific categories with enhanced authentication requirements

proposer.position: Enhanced UPI limits require additional authentication beyond UPI PIN. Recommend implementing device binding verification, biometric confirmation, and transaction velocity checks for all high-value UPI payments.
reasoning: Rs. 5 lakh transactions significantly increase fraud exposure
NPCI circular mandates 'additional factor of authentication'
Device binding prevents SIM swap fraud

critic.position: Over-engineering authentication will create friction and drive users to alternatives. NPCI circular mentions 'risk-based authentication' not blanket requirements. Need intelligent auth that balances security with user experience.
reasoning: UPI success depends on frictionless experience
Trusted devices with transaction history need less auth
Risk scoring should determine auth level

judge.decision: Implement tiered authentication: Standard UPI PIN for transactions up to Rs. 1 lakh from trusted devices. Device binding + OTP for Rs. 1-3 lakh. Biometric + cooling period for Rs. 3-5 lakh. Real-time fraud scoring to escalate auth level dynamically.
judge.requirement: Risk-based authentication tiers for high-value UPI with fraud scoring integration
reasoning: Balances security with user experience
Higher value = higher assurance level
Dynamic fraud scoring adds intelligence
